stream_context.summary: Kaze blockouts and iterates on the Snowman Cave’s platforming layout (rooms/sections, elevator behavior, camera shake, visuals), discusses performance/graphics tradeoffs on real N64 hardware, and shares major real-life timeline news (impending birth of his daughter) plus broader plans (Course 1 demo feedback doc, future open-source optimization backport, hiring an editor).
stream_context.significance_reason: A major personal timeline event is announced (daughter likely born in ~5 days, possible streaming hiatus), alongside concrete production plans (Course 1 demo with structured feedback collection, content release schedule, editor hire) and explicit philosophical/technical constraints (staying within N64-era memory limits, real-console testing/optimization).

findings.summary: Kaze says his daughter is likely to be born in about five days, so he may not be able to stream next week depending on hospital timing; he also reveals the baby’s name is already decided (Rainer/Reyna, clarified as 'Rainer' later).
findings.quote: In five days, my daughter is likely going to be born—meaning I might not be able to stream next week.

findings.summary: The stream’s main dev goal is the Snowman Cave: Kaze outlines a room plan centered on a climbable slide where a snowman attacks, a void-platform section, and the need for a final slide-down transition into an end room (possibly a coin/star treasure room).
He plans to fix character shadow issues by making the shadow a separate object from Mario that independently finds the floor, avoiding problems caused by Mario’s floor logic when jumping on objects.

Kaze is tuning enemy behavior in Snowman Cave (attack rate and distance logic), noting it shouldn’t be so fast that the player can’t progress up the slide and that vertical distance checks are needed (not only lateral).
He discusses changing RDP/RSP pipeline usage (n-prim vs 1-prim): after switching, only dialogue required adjustment; performance gains were small (~1 FPS) and require correct pipe syncs.

Kaze showcases his improved real-N64 testing workflow: he can build and launch quickly onto hardware (via flashcart/EverDrive-style setup), though he still has about half a second of input delay that makes playtesting harder.

He iterates on environmental feel and readability: current Snowman Cave geometry is intentionally ugly/placeholder while greyboxing; he rejects certain materials (wood blocks) and searches reference imagery for ice cave aesthetics (pillars, rocks, cliffs).

Kaze tunes an elevator/camera shake effect, removing unused code paths and experimenting with parameters (magnitude/detail/FOV vs pitch shake), ultimately leaning toward reducing or removing FOV shake because it reads like a camera bug.

He outlines near-term release/feedback plans: a Course 1 demo is targeted soon, paired with a Google Doc questionnaire to collect granular feedback on physics and camera so he can make small adjustments toward the 'right' feel.

Kaze shares a content schedule: an 'F3' video around the 27th, a 'random matrices' video around early August, and then (ideally) the Course 1 demo; he recorded the matrices voiceover and has someone helping edit to improve quality and save time.

He has started paying an editor (~$16 per minute of finished video, roughly $200/video), and believes scaling output could plausibly push the channel toward 1M subscribers via many Mario 64-focused videos (bugs, '100 improvements', etc.).
Kaze states Nintendo has taken down about 70 of his videos in the past, framing it as long-running hostility toward his Mario mod content.
findings.quote: They took down 70 of my videos, just so you are aware of how much they hate me.

findings.summary: He says he hasn’t released the project’s optimizations as a separate patch yet, but after the main project is done he may start an open-source effort to port RTYI optimizations back to vanilla Mario 64 so others can contribute.

Kaze explicitly frames staying within original-era hardware limits as part of the creative challenge: even if newer hardware could provide effectively 'infinite' room, he doesn’t want people to dismiss RTYI as 'cheating' by using more memory than the time allowed (he cites not wanting to exceed ~64MB as a principle).
findings.quote: If I don't stay within the original limitations, am I not kind of cheating?

biobak.summary: Kaze describes Biobak’s role as a second-pass reviewer on models: after Kaze finishes a model, Biobak looks it over and improves how it looks.

badub.summary: Kaze reiterates Badub is creating music for the project (mentioned while listing who is helping).

zeina.summary: Zeina briefly appears during a household interruption: Kaze asks her to clarify to her brother that there was buried wire/cable at the bottom of their property after the brother cut into it while working near an automatic lawnmower setup.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: In five days, my daughter is likely going to be born—meaning I might not be able to stream next week.
memorable_quotes.context: A clear timeline anchor for production: impending birth, probable streaming disruption, and an implicit shift in work/life rhythm.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: They took down 70 of my videos, just so you are aware of how much they hate me.
memorable_quotes.context: Blunt statement of his long-running conflict with Nintendo and the tangible cost (deleted work/history) that shapes his creator journey.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: If I don't stay within the original limitations, am I not kind of cheating?
memorable_quotes.context: A succinct articulation of the project’s guiding ethos: the hack is not just 'bigger Mario 64,' but a self-imposed authenticity challenge.

key_stories.title: Impending birth and a likely streaming hiatus
key_stories.summary: Mid-development, Kaze shares that his daughter is expected in roughly five days. This becomes a concrete production constraint that may pause streams and compress near-term goals (demo/content plans) around a major life milestone.
key_stories.challenge: Balancing late-stage hack development and public streaming cadence with the unpredictability of childbirth and hospital timing.
key_stories.process: He informs the audience early, sets expectations that next week’s streams may not happen, and continues planning deliverables (videos/demo) around the date.
key_stories.outcome: The documentary timeline gains a clear external deadline and a likely break in public-facing development; the baby’s name is stated as decided (Rainer/Reyna).
key_stories.key_quote: In five days, my daughter is likely going to be born—meaning I might not be able to stream next week.

key_stories.title: Designing Snowman Cave as a sequence of distinct platforming rooms
key_stories.summary: Kaze uses the stream to define what Snowman Cave 'is' at a structural level: a climb/slide under attack, a void-platform climb, then a needed slide-down into an end room. The work is presented as greyboxing-first, aesthetics-later, with active iteration based on feel and readability.
key_stories.challenge: The level has only a couple of good sections at first; Kaze needs enough variety to feel complete while keeping a tight theme (mostly snowmen).
key_stories.process: He outlines room ideas, tests jump lines and failure cases, adjusts geometry to avoid frustrating wall push-outs, and searches for ice-cave visual references while rejecting placeholder materials that clash (e.g., wood blocks).
key_stories.outcome: A tentative room plan emerges (including a final slide and end room concept), with next stream explicitly planned to build the void slide and finish the second star’s platforming pathing.

key_stories.title: A structured Course 1 demo plan built around player feedback
key_stories.summary: Rather than treating a demo as marketing, Kaze frames it as an instrument calibration step for the game’s core feel. He plans to pair the Course 1 demo with a questionnaire so he can tune physics and camera via small, targeted adjustments.
key_stories.challenge: Getting 'minuscule' physics and camera feel correct without a broad tester base or clear objective metrics.
key_stories.process: He proposes releasing a Course 1 demo and collecting responses in a Google Doc focused on specific dimensions (physics feel, camera behavior, etc.).
key_stories.outcome: A clear next milestone is set: a feedback-driven iteration loop that could materially shape the final movement/camera identity of RTYI.

key_stories.title: Nintendo enforcement as an ongoing backdrop
key_stories.summary: Kaze states Nintendo has removed roughly 70 of his videos, positioning it as a long-term adversarial force in his Mario mod career. This contextualizes why he’s cautious about perceptions, distribution, and legitimacy of his work.
key_stories.challenge: Sustaining a public-facing Mario mod presence despite takedowns that erase output and create uncertainty.
key_stories.process: He references the number of removed videos in direct response to chat discussion about Nintendo’s potential actions.
key_stories.outcome: The stream provides a concrete data point (70 takedowns) and a tonal snapshot of how personally he experiences the conflict.
key_stories.key_quote: They took down 70 of my videos, just so you are aware of how much they hate me.

open_questions.topic: Shadow fix via a separate 'shadow actor' object
open_questions.context: Kaze says he intends to fix shadow issues by divorcing the shadow from Mario and having it find the floor independently, because Mario’s floor logic has edge cases when interacting with objects.
questions: What specific shadow bugs were players noticing, and how often did they show up during normal play?
What edge cases in Mario’s existing floor detection made a separate shadow object necessary?
How will you validate the fix across moving platforms, slopes, and multi-floor situations without introducing new artifacts?

open_questions.topic: Course 1 demo feedback document and iteration plan
open_questions.context: Kaze wants to release a Course 1 demo and collect structured feedback (physics and camera) to make 'minuscule adjustments' until the feel is right.
questions: What questions will you ask players so the feedback is actionable rather than subjective noise?
How will you decide when physics/camera are 'done'—do you have target reference behaviors or metrics?
Will you weight feedback differently for new players vs Mario 64 veterans vs speedrunners?

open_questions.topic: Staying within N64-era constraints as a creative ethic
open_questions.context: Kaze argues that exceeding original memory limits would feel like 'cheating' and invites dismissive reactions (why not just use emulator/new hardware), even though more memory is theoretically available.
questions: Which constraints are non-negotiable for you (ROM size, RAM, CPU time, microcode choices), and why those specifically?
Have you had moments where breaking a constraint would have solved a major problem—what did you do instead?
How do you want players to feel the constraints in the final game: invisible, or subtly part of the charm?

open_questions.topic: Open-sourcing and backporting RTYI optimizations to vanilla Mario 64
open_questions.context: Kaze says he hasn’t released an optimization pack yet but may start an open-source project after RTYI is done to port improvements back to vanilla Mario 64.
questions: Which optimizations are you most proud of, and which ones would actually generalize cleanly to vanilla Mario 64?
What’s the reason for waiting until after RTYI is finished—time, risk, project focus, or something else?
If it becomes an open-source effort, what parts would you want others to contribute versus what must stay curated to avoid regressions?
